text:
OK, the next topic we're
going to talk about

is convolutional neural
networks or CNNs.
And this is what's used--

commonly used these days for
classifying natural images

or images of any kind, but in
particular, natural images.

And here's a palette
of natural images.

You've seen hundreds
different images here.

This is a data set that
it's known as a CIFAR100,

and the 100 stands for 100
different image classes.

So you can see there's fish,
animals, butterflies, cars.

So they're natural images, and
they fall into 100 classes.
So that's a lot of classes.

And each image is a
32 by 32 color image.

OK, so that's a little different
to what we worked with before.

And neural networks, when
they re-emerged in 2010,

their big success story
was classifying images.
They got spectacular results.

And as a result of having
these much larger training

sets and much better
computing power.

For CIFAR100, there's 50,000
training images and 10,000 test
images.

Now, each image here is
a three-dimensional array
or feature map.

So that means that it's got a
red, green, and blue channel.
So that's the third dimension.

And the other two channels, the
red, green, and blue channels

are images that are
going to look like these,

but they represent the
three different colors,

and each of those is
going to be 32 by 32.

This is just a little
schematic that sort of gives
the intuition of CNN's work.

So what it does, we've got a
little cartoon image of a tiger.

And the CNN builds
up an image in a kind
of hierarchical fashion.

First, it tries to identify
little shapes or little color

splotches or edges or so on in
the image, but small, typically
small.

So you can see in this
cartoon, it's picked up an ear,

it's picked up part
of the mouth maybe.
There's a little bit of red.
That's the tongue.

So these are really small,
little localized parts
of the image.

And then, if you
go up the layers,

these here are used
as building blocks

to build up more composite
aspects of the images--

a piece together to form more
complex shapes, eventually
assembling the target image.

And this hierarchical
construction

is achieved using what's
known as convolution
and pooling layers.

And that's where
the name convolution

is where the CNN comes from
Convolutional Neural Networks.

So we're going to
tell you about both

of these layers, the
convolutional filter
and the pooling layer.

So here, we're showing
you using little matrices
how convolution filter works.

So let's suppose your
input image was this one,

and we've read this represented
the pixels as letters.

And the convolution filter
is itself a little image
and it's small.

Yeah, we've shown a convolution
filter which is just 2 by 2,

so it's just four numbers
arranged in a 2 by 2 array.

Now what we do is we
take this 2 by 2 array

and we move it on top of the
left hand part of the image.

So it sits on top of
these four numbers.

And then we multiply the
elements together and sum them
up.

So you can see that's
what's happened over here.

We multiplied them
together and sum them up.

So the a times the alpha, the
b times the beta, and so on.

Then we slide this filter along
to the right just one column.
So they're overlapping.
And we do it again.

And so there you
can see what's known

as a dot-product
between this little 2
by 2 block and this filter.
And then we do it.

We then we move down a
row, and we do it again.

So now we use these
four guys here.

That's what's going on
over here and so on.

So that operation is
known as a convolution.

You've got a filter,
you've got the big image,

and you do this
convolution where

you slide this little
filter around the image
and do these dot-products.

So the way it works
is if the little sub

image over which we hover in the
filter is similar to the filter,

then that dot-product
computes a large number.

In other words, it's
detected something

that looks like
itself in that place.

Otherwise, it'll
be a small number.
The number will be low.

So If this fault is any
good, what it's going to do

is, it's going to
make a new image.

And that image is going to
highlight parts of the image

where this little image
was seen basically
or close to being seen?

And the other nice
thing is that we don't
supply these little filters.

They learned when you
learn the network,

and we're going to
have many of them.
So here's an illustration.

Target image is a tiger,
and we've got two filters.

Let's pretend these
filters were learned.

And so these are two
small little filters.

And so you can see this
one's got a vertical stripe

with two black stripes and
a vertical white stripe.

This one's got a
horizontal stripe.

And we do the convolution
over the image.

They're going to look for
vertical and horizontal stripes
in the image.

And it's not 100%
clear, but you can

see when we do the
vertical stripe

one, this image
of the tiger tends
to accentuate vertical stripes.

And when we do the
horizontal stripe one,

it tends to accentuate
the horizontal stripes.

Again, not perfect, but
it's kind of doing the job.

So the result of the convolution
is a new feature map.

So this image here consists of
red, green, and blue channels.

We just shown one fault here,
but it's got red, green,
and blue channels.

But when you do the convolution,
it produces a new image, also
what we call a feature map.

So since images
have three colors,

it turns out these
filters do have as well.

So you'll have a filter for the
red, the filter for the green,
and the filter for the blue.

And then you do the
dot-product separately

on the red, green, and blue,
and then you add up the results.

And so, from one color image,
you get one new feature map.
So that's the convolution.

And again, the
weights in the filters
are learned in the network.

We'll tell you a bit more
about that in a moment,

but let me tell you
also about pooling.

So, yes, let's say the
feature map that we obtained
from doing a convolution.
What pooling does is--
and this is called max pooling.

It takes non-overlapping
blocks, in this case,

2 by 2 blocks, which is
what we actually use.

And we replace each
block by its maximum.

So here's the
first 2 by 2 block.
It's got 1, 2, 3, and 0.
The maximum value in there is 3.
So we put in a 3.
The next block is 5, 3, 1, 2.
The maximum there is 5.
We put 5, and so on.

And so you get a reduced image
which has got 3, 5, 2, and 4.

So this sharpens the
feature identification.

If we thought of the convolution
as highlighting areas
where we saw a feature--

by doing this pooling,
we sharpen things

and we allow a little bit
of location invariance

to where that
feature is by picking
the place where it's maximum.

It also reduces the
dimension by a factor of 4.

So in this case, a factor
of 2 in each dimension.

OK, so here's the
architecture of a CNN.

You'll see there's many
convolve and pooling layers.
Here's the first convolve layer.

And you can see we've got a
number of feature maps here.
The input image was 32.

We come out with these
feature maps are 32 by 32.

Well, how come
there are so many?

Well, for each filter that we
have, we get a new feature map.

And so in this case, we've
got 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.

OK, well, now we think
of these new feature maps

as new channels
along this hierarchy,

we had three color
channels for the input.

We've now created
eight channels.

We then do a pool,
a max pool layer,

and say the filters are
typically small example 3 by 3.

Each filter creates
a new channel
in the convolution layer.
And in this case, we see 8.

As a pooling reduces the size,
the number of filters channels
is typically increased.
OK, so we had 8 here.

We still have eight
here, but they've

dropped in size to half the
dimensions in each direction.

And now we have filters that
get applied to these guys.
But now, remember this.
We see in eight channels here.

So the filter has to have
eight channels as well.

Remember, we had three channels
in the filter for the input.
We've got eight channels here.

Each filter has eight channels,
one for each of these feature
maps here.

And because things are
getting smaller in size,
we have more filters.
And so then the output becomes--

we increase the number of
feature maps that we produce.

What's happening here-- we're
going-- we start on the left

with the features are
very local, very fine.

And then as you pool and
convolve-- pool and convolve,

the features are
more and more coarse.
Is that right?
Yes.

They're not as local
as you move up?

Yeah, that's right
because that max pooling

is allowing the feature to sort
of move around and get localized

and sort of zone in where
it is because you could
have two images of a tiger.

And even though they've been
standardized in some way,

it could be in different
places for sure.

And so this allows that
kind of location invariance.

So it's almost like looking
through the camera and the lens,

you start very close, and then
you sort of pan back, right?
Yes.
So this carries on.

We keep on going, and we
have a max pool layer.

Then we have another
convolve layer.

Each time the max pool drops
dimensions and the images

get smaller and
smaller, and we actually

go all the way until we're down
to some really small images
like 2 by 2.

And then we just
collapse what's known

as flattening into the
individual pixels in all

those images and we have
a fully connected layer

to the output layer where
there's hundreds classes.
So that's how it works.

And like we say, the number
of layers can be very large.

So there's one network that was
trained on a 1,000-class image
database known as image net.
And it's got 50 layers,

So here you see in
about eight layers.

This one's got 50
layers, and we're

going to demonstrate
it in a little while.

In fact, we demonstrated
it right now.

So just to remind
you, the parameters

or the weights in these
networks are the filters.

If we go back to our
little filters here,

you can see these
four numbers here

are weights that
need to be learned.

For a color image, we're
going to have three channels.

So there's going to be 4 times
3 is 12 weights for one filter.

If you have many filters,
the weights add up.

Then when you go to these ones
here, we got eight channels.

So now each filter
has eight channels.

So the number of weights in
each filter is 8 times, say--
we said 3 by 3 for this CNN.
So they add up.

So those-- that's where the
parameters come in and they get
learned during training.

So there's image nets-- one
big image training database.
There's even bigger ones today.

And massive neural networks are
trained on these image databases

and trained using distributed
software by companies
like Google and Facebook.

And the nice thing is they
make these pre-trained networks
available.

So here's a collection
of photographs

taken from a photograph
album of natural images,

and we're going to use
a pre-trained ResNet

network to try and
classify these images.

And in the lab, we
go through how we--
we show you how to do that.

But here we're just
going to show the result.

And this procedure is going to
produce probabilities for each

of the 100, in this
case, 1,000 classes.

But we're going to
show the top three.

And for the first one,
it says gives 0.83
probability to flamingo.
And indeed, it was a flamingo.

This guy is known
as a Cooper's hawk.

They abundant in
Northern California.

It calls it a kite, which
is a kind of raptor.

It gives 60%
probability to that.

Second guess is
a great gray owl.

Third guess with very
small probability
is a robin that's way off.

Here we zoom out of the
Cooper's hawk picture,

and you can see it's
sitting on a water fountain.
And the network gets confused.

So now it classifies this
picture as a fountain,
and ignores the hawk.

And then it seems to go off the
rails because the next guess is
a hook--

a nail and then the
next one is a hook.

Here's a picture of
a cute little dog.

He's actually a
Lhasa Apso, which
is a kind of Tibetan guard dog.

It gets classified
as a Tibetan terrier

and they look somewhat similar
and with 56% probability.

And then the second guess is
a Lhasa, which is correct.

And the third is
a Cocker Spaniel.

Here is a cat lying in
a curled up position.

And this completely
fooled the network.

It thought it was an
old English sheepdog.

Way down in the list is a
Persian cat and slightly
high as a Shih-Tzu dog.

And the last one-- this is a
Cape weaver bird in its nest.

And it gets classified
as a jacamar, which

is a kind of bird that
hangs out in trees
and builds nests in trees.

It's second and third
guess are also birds.

Can you go back to the
picture of the CNN.

I just was unclear
about something.

When you say pre-trained--
so when you apply this now

to the photographs, which part
is obtained from the database

and which weights are
trained for this data?
Oh, I see.

In this case, Rob,
we took the network

as is and just
classified the images.

Also, there was no
training at all?
There's no training.
[INAUDIBLE]

In this case, there
is no training.

But I think you're getting
onto another point, which
is interesting as well, Rob--

about using pre-trained
networks for other tasks.

So when you train a neural
network on natural images,

either, you know, let's say the
ResNet one that we have here,

a lot of the early
layers of the network

are just picking up
features in natural images.

And a lot of the training
goes to learning those.

And you may have a problem where
you've got, say, medical images,

you know, of lungs or mammograms
or something like that.

And those pre-trained features
can be helpful in, you know,

in classifying or
diagnosing medical images.

So what you can do
is you can pick out

those pre-trained layers
from an image network

and then you can use
some training data

for the problem at hand to
learn the remaining layers.

And I guess the one
is, for mammograms,

you might typically only
have a few hundred training

observations, but their
pre-training might come from
100,000 images.

So there's a lot more
data for the pre-training.
